props.name: disabled
props.docs: Wether or not the component is actually disabled.

props.name: href
props.docs: Optional, if provided, the button contains an a11y-anchor inside.

props.name: state
props.docs: What state the button has.

props.name: target
props.docs: If "to" is provided, should the link have a target be set?

props.name: theme
props.docs: What kind of default-provided theme shall be applied.

props.name: type
props.docs: What kind of button this one is.

components.docs:
Collects buttons. Horizontally. Supports `--gap`.
If `autohide` is true, any items which to not fit will be
rendered as <msc-item /> within an Menu.

props.name: autohideItems
props.docs:
Hide's the last X items that don't fit to the parent container.
items will be re-rendered as <msc-item />

props.name: href
props.docs: Link where to go to when click

props.name: target
props.docs:
if an href (usually called "to" as attribute/prop) is provided,
should there be a specific target type applied?

components.docs: TODO: Allow Animations; set duration via css-var

props.name: alignX
props.docs:
Overwrites the placement of content (NOT items!) on the horizontal axis
See flexbox values
May swap with horizontal alignment for correct behaviour

props.name: alignY
props.docs:
Overwrite placement of content (NOT items!) on the vertical axis
See flexbox values
May swap with horizontal alignment for correct behaviour

props.name: center
props.docs: Centers the content of this container (NOT items!) on both axis.

props.name: contentScroll
props.docs: Enables purposefully scrolling for the content of this tag.

props.name: trackX
props.docs:
Changes the placement direction of this container.
See flexbox specs. Applies "weird behaviour" fixes of flexbox.

props.name: trackY
props.docs:
Changes the placement direction of this container.
See flexbox specs. Applies "weird behaviour" fixes of flexbox.

components.docs: Utilizes DataProvider Service to define the children asap the component can be initialized.

props.name: base
props.docs: The minimum width of an item of the grid

props.name: centerContent
props.docs: Center container of all item-containers?

props.name: centerItems
props.docs: Center grid items in their item-container?

props.name: gap
props.docs: The minimum width of an item of the grid

props.name: squared
props.docs: Should every cell's height equal to it's --base width?

props.name: template
props.docs: Define's the grid-template

components.docs: TODO: This class is still buggy for subsequent updates.

props.name: name
props.docs:
The iconName to resolve. This is dependant on how you declared your own
IconSet.

props.name: set
props.docs:
The IconSet to pick the icon-name from.
If not provied, the `defaultIconSet` is used from ApplicationService.

props.name: autocomplete
props.docs:
Should this input field autocomplete?
Ignored for type="radio" and type="checkbox"

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Is your input disabled?

props.name: name
props.docs: Under what name should the value be stored inside the form?

props.name: placeholder
props.docs: The value to display when there is no value.

props.name: required
props.docs: Is your input required?

props.name: type
props.docs: The type of input you need.

props.name: value
props.docs: The value the component has/holds.

events.docs: CustomEvent that dispatches when the content changes.

props.name: href
props.docs:
An attribute/prop that is usually exposed as "to" which intern will
open the provided link when activated.
Or whatever the criteria is.
!IMPORTANT! To make your life easier, be sure to set the prop to "reflect" the current value!

props.name: target
props.docs:
if an href (usually called "to" as attribute/prop) is provided,
should there be a specific target type applied?

components.docs:
If you provide custom actions and those need to onAffirm or onReject, don't
forget to add data-positive or data-negative!

props.name: closingX
props.docs: Show's an closing-X at the top right.

props.name: displayMessage
props.docs:
The important message you need to devliever to your user.
If an array is supplied, each item will be wrapped in an paragraph.

props.name: displayNegativeText
props.docs:
If provided, this value is used to render the default, negative button.
Only needed to overwrite the text, you can also overwrite the whole button
if you define "data-negative" as attribute inside your slot named action.

props.name: displayPositiveText
props.docs:
If provided, this value is used to render the default, positive button.
Only needed to overwrite the text, you can also overwrite the whole button
if you define "data-positive" as attribute inside your slot named action.

props.name: displayTitle
props.docs: The title to display at the top. Supply a falsy value to disclose.

props.name: global
props.docs:
Don't position using "absolute".
Ignore parent, use position "fixed" when true.

props.name: isVisible
props.docs:
*** DO NOT SET THIS VALUE BY HAND; THIS IS READONLY/INITIAL ASSIGNMENT ***
If you're using a framework, you can set it. Otherwise, no.
Call myModal.toggle() in html. Designed for JSX assignment.

props.name: omittedActions
props.docs:
Not only can you overwrite the texts and buttons that are present by default,
using this prop you are also be able to exclude certain actions.
E.g. Dialogs.alert() will omit the negative action.

props.name: role
props.docs: Defines the Modal-Role. Is it a dismissable alert or dialog?

methods.name: close
methods.docs: Closes the modal, even if it's already closed.

methods.name: open
methods.docs: Opens the modal, even if it's already open.

methods.name: toggle
methods.docs:
Invert's the current visibillity state.
But you can also define a specific visibillity state as argument,
but might wanna try `show()` or `close()` first.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text: newState The new forcefully defined state

events.docs:
Event and static prop to define what happens when the user
wants to proceed.
This may be the "apply", or "ok" button, it's usually also theme="primary"
You can listen on this actions usinmg "affirm".

Custom event that gets triggered whenever this instance changes it's `isVisible`
property.
Access the value using `detail`.
Access the modal using `target`.

Event and static prop to define what happens when the user does NOT
want to proceed.
This may be the "cancel", or "reset" button, it's usually is rendered with default styles.
You can listen on this actions usinmg "reject".

methods.name: ongoing
methods.signature: ongoing(requests: Request[], aborted?: Error | Response) => Promise<void>
methods.docs: Ongoing requests reported lazily by ApiService

props.name: autoShow
props.docs: Should the Sidebar expand when you're near it?

props.name: fixed
props.docs: If true, styling applies position: fixed instead of position: absolute

props.name: keepOpen
props.docs: Should the Sidebar always be open?

props.name: overlay
props.docs:
Wether or not the sidebar should take up space in the document.
If true, full content is exposed on hovering/tap.

props.name: side
props.docs: If true, styling applies position: fixed instead of position: absolute

props.name: single
props.docs: Controls wether or not only one item can be expanded.

methods.name: toggle
methods.docs: Inverts current state or forces a specific state

props.name: dismissable
props.docs: If true, toast will be gone when clicked.

props.name: indicator
props.docs:
If true, only the most important things are rendered to make the toast work.
Pure extendabillity for your!

props.name: message
props.docs: The message to show in the Toast.

props.name: messageTitle
props.docs: A small string that's rendered <**bold** />

props.name: state
props.docs: Visual state how the tosat looks

props.name: timeout
props.docs: How long the toast shall be visible. Use a falsy value for no timeout.

components.readme:
# msc-tooltip

The "tooltip" is an essential component that helps you to define a more descriptive message for another element.

It also helps you to describe icons and any other component(s) that aren't descriptive enough by default for disabled users.

ATTENTION: This component will always add itself as last element to the viewport.
This is to ensure that the tooltip is always visible in any case, additionally, it ensures that nested - scrollable views, do not conflict in the global viewport offset.

Just keep in mind that you declare the component context-based, but the component itself is rendered globally, while maintaining it's created context.

You can also overwrite the target-context by providing a "for" selector.
components.docs:
The "tooltip" is an essential component that helps you to define a more descriptive message for another element.

It also helps you to describe icons and any other component(s) that aren't descriptive enough by default for disabled users.

ATTENTION: This component will always add itself as last element to the viewport.
This is to ensure that the tooltip is always visible in any case, additionally, it ensures that nested - scrollable views, do not conflict in the global viewport offset.

Just keep in mind that you declare the component context-based, but the component itself is rendered globally, while maintaining it's created context.

You can also overwrite the target-context by providing a "for" selector.

props.name: for
props.docs:
Idenficator (id) for targeted element. Fallback to <slot/> if not provided.
Tooltip will be placed relative to the found element.
If the element is not found, the component will break (but a developer notice will be logged).

props.name: global
props.docs:
All tooltips are now globally positioned by default.
It's just better.

props.name: label
props.docs: What should the displayed within the tooltip?

props.name: position
props.docs:
Where the actual tooltip needs to be positioned.
Ignored when there is no space.
